segment.source: WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive
segment.target: WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive

segment.source: WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive
segment.target: WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive

segment.source: WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive
segment.target: WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive

segment.source: Create a Windows PE (WinPE) bootable USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive.
segment.target: Create a Windows PE (WinPE) bootable USB flash drive or an external USB hard drive.

segment.source: The default installation runs from memory (RAM disk), so you can remove the drive while Windows PE is running.
segment.target: The default installation runs from memory (RAM disk), so you can remove the drive while Windows PE is running.

segment.source: Install the Windows ADK
segment.target: Install the Windows ADK

segment.source: Install the following features from the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK):
segment.target: Install the following features from the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK):

segment.source: Deployment Tools: includes the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment.
segment.target: Deployment Tools: includes the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment.

segment.source: Windows Preinstallation Environment : includes the files used to install Windows PE.
segment.target: Windows Preinstallation Environment : includes the files used to install Windows PE.

segment.source: Install Windows PE
segment.target: Install Windows PE

segment.source: Start the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment as an administrator.
segment.target: Start the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment as an administrator.

segment.source: Create a working copy of the Windows PE files.
segment.target: Create a working copy of the Windows PE files.

segment.source: Specify either x86, amd64, or arm:
segment.target: Specify either x86, amd64, or arm:

segment.source: Install Windows PE to the USB flash drive, specifying the drive letter:
segment.target: Install Windows PE to the USB flash drive, specifying the drive letter:

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: This command reformats the drive.
segment.target: This command reformats the drive.

segment.source: Boot to Windows PE
segment.target: Boot to Windows PE

segment.source: Connect the USB device to the PC you want to work on.
segment.target: Connect the USB device to the PC you want to work on.

segment.source: Turn on the PC, and press the key that opens the firmware boot menus.
segment.target: Turn on the PC, and press the key that opens the firmware boot menus.

segment.source: Select the USB drive.
segment.target: Select the USB drive.

segment.source: Windows PE starts automatically.
segment.target: Windows PE starts automatically.

segment.source: After the command window appears, the command runs, which sets up the system.
segment.target: After the command window appears, the command runs, which sets up the system.

segment.source: This might take a few minutes.
segment.target: This might take a few minutes.

segment.source: Troubleshooting
segment.target: Troubleshooting

segment.source: If the command isn't recognized, make sure you're running the command from the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, which is part of the Windows ADK.
segment.target: If the command isn't recognized, make sure you're running the command from the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, which is part of the Windows ADK.

segment.source: If Windows PE doesn't appear, try the following workarounds, rebooting the PC each time:
segment.target: If Windows PE doesn't appear, try the following workarounds, rebooting the PC each time:

segment.source: To boot a PC that supports UEFI mode, in the firmware boot menus, try manually selecting the boot files: EFIBOOTBOOTX64.EFI.
segment.target: To boot a PC that supports UEFI mode, in the firmware boot menus, try manually selecting the boot files: EFIBOOTBOOTX64.EFI.

segment.source: Try a different USB port.
segment.target: Try a different USB port.

segment.source: Avoid hubs or cables.
segment.target: Avoid hubs or cables.

segment.source: Avoid USB 3.0 ports if the firmware doesn't contain native support for USB 3.0.
segment.target: Avoid USB 3.0 ports if the firmware doesn't contain native support for USB 3.0.

segment.source: Clean the USB flash drive, and then reinstall Windows PE.
segment.target: Clean the USB flash drive, and then reinstall Windows PE.

segment.source: This can help remove extra boot partitions or other boot software.
segment.target: This can help remove extra boot partitions or other boot software.

segment.source: Try booting Windows PE from a DVD instead.
segment.target: Try booting Windows PE from a DVD instead.

segment.source: Create an ISO file that you can burn onto a DVD:
segment.target: Create an ISO file that you can burn onto a DVD:

segment.source: In File Explorer, navigate to C:winpeamd64, right-click winpe.iso, and select Burn to disc.
segment.target: In File Explorer, navigate to C:winpeamd64, right-click winpe.iso, and select Burn to disc.

segment.source: Follow the prompts to create a DVD.
segment.target: Follow the prompts to create a DVD.

segment.source: If your PC requires storage or video drivers to boot, try adding those same drivers to the Windows PE image.
segment.target: If your PC requires storage or video drivers to boot, try adding those same drivers to the Windows PE image.

segment.source: For more info, see WinPE: Mount and Customize.
segment.target: For more info, see WinPE: Mount and Customize.

segment.source: Update the firmware of the PC to the latest version.
segment.target: Update the firmware of the PC to the latest version.

segment.source: If the PC doesn't connect to network locations, see WinPE Network Drivers: Initializing and adding drivers.
segment.target: If the PC doesn't connect to network locations, see WinPE Network Drivers: Initializing and adding drivers.

segment.source: Storing Windows Images on the Windows PE Drive
segment.target: Storing Windows Images on the Windows PE Drive

segment.source: Typically you won't be able to store or capture Windows images on a Windows PE USB flash drive.
segment.target: Typically you won't be able to store or capture Windows images on a Windows PE USB flash drive.

segment.source: Most USB flash drives support only a single drive partition.
segment.target: Most USB flash drives support only a single drive partition.

segment.source: The command formats the drive as FAT32, which supports booting both BIOS-based and UEFI-based PCs.
segment.target: The command formats the drive as FAT32, which supports booting both BIOS-based and UEFI-based PCs.

segment.source: This file format only supports file sizes up to 4 GB.
segment.target: This file format only supports file sizes up to 4 GB.

segment.source: For external USB hard drives, you can create a separate NTFS partition that can handle larger file sizes:
segment.target: For external USB hard drives, you can create a separate NTFS partition that can handle larger file sizes:
